# 9.6 Creating a Web Index: JOURNX477-032 Indexing: Theory and Application

## 9.6 Creating a Web Index

![notepad](https://onlinelearning.berkeley.edu/courses/1939224/files/233565849/preview)_From the desk of ... Fred Brown_  
Fred Brown has over ten years of technical communication experience working largely with high-technology firms that specialize in software and telecommunications. He now specializes in indexes and navigation aids for Web sites. Fred won the Australian Society of Indexers (AusSI) Web Indexing Award for the index he created using MACREX for the since discontinued Writer's Block website.

While there are several approaches and software packages available for indexing a Web site, Fred will explain his own indexing process using MACREX. Before continuing, you might want to read [a definition of Web indexing![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)Links to an external site.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_indexing).

### Creating a Web Index Using MACREX

1\. Establish a business case for a Web index or other navigation aid. For example, it could

-   Increase repeat business
-   Encourage word-of-mouth advertising
-   Reduce customer support costs
-   Improve worker productivity

2\. Understand your audience in terms of

-   Basic demographics
-   Knowledge/education
-   Types of information sought
-   Experience with the Web

3\. Assess the contents of the website in terms of

-   Size of site
-   Structure
-   Any other navigation aids
-   Writing style
-   Consistency of terminology
-   Type and range of material
-   Rate of change

4\. Evaluate the Web indexing option in relation to other website search and navigation alternatives, such as

-   Taxonomies and online thesauri
-   Topic maps
-   Search engines

5\. Establish the specifications for the Web index:

-   Define scope (link to pages within the website only or include pages referenced that lie outside the website itself?)
-   Decide the level of detail in the website to which to link (whole HTML pages only; specific sections within HTML pages starting with a heading; paragraphs with HTML pages)
-   Decide whether to have one or many hypertext links for each heading in the index
-   Decide how to handle PDF, video, audio, and other non-HTML files
-   Decide formatting (navigation within the index; font/color; look and feel standards of a Web site)
-   Assess maintenance requirements (frequency; expected changes and impact on the index; who)

6\. Develop a prototype index (contact Gale Rhoades <macrex@wisebytes.biz> for technical assistance):

-   Create a project tracking scheme (Web pages indexed; time)
-   Create any special MACREX files for Web indexing (e.g., LAY, MWP)
-   Create any macros (e.g., for inserting hypertext links)
-   Select a few pages from the website
-   Print and read the website pages
-   Mark the index entries on the printed Web pages (both regular entries and cross-references)
-   Enter the index entries in MACREX
-   Link the cross-references
-   Output the Web index and take a look
-   Adjust formatting
-   Review lessons learned and make any necessary changes

7\. Create the Web index

-   Print and read the website pages
-   Mark the index entries on the printed website pages
-   Enter any necessary "targets" in the Web pages (may be done by the Web master)
-   Enter the index entries into MACREX (using the URLs as page numbers; watch for main headings that are cross-referenced)
-   Edit the index
-   Link the cross-references
-   Output the index
-   Test every link plus the cross-references
-   Adjust index format

Two different examples of Web indexes:
